FreeResponse: Because a human would need to take control under certain circumstances. So, this always needs to be an option.
The results could go either way. I am in between on this topic. It could be either good or bad to make a final decision.

I feel that the CEO's decision to move forward with half the cars not having human override capability was totally inappropriate because it does NOT balance freedom with safety, as his stated position asserts. As long as there are ANY safety concerns, those should be addressed before putting any drivers behind the wheel.
I have the same belief that he had that humans should have freedom to choice if they want to drive or not. Especially in an emergency or unseen circumstances the car can't predict.
You should be able to control what is going on in the car. If an accident were about to happen you could prevent it where a self driving car couldn't.
I think it is very appropriate to test the best way to have humans override the self driving car.  People will want this option and will want it to work in the best possible way.
It's a good way to make the transition and gives drivers an option, a choice and a sense of control.
There are too many variables when driving to not provide the driver with over ride options.
It's my biggest concern with self driving cars. I think it's a rational experiment

Something could go wrong with the cars computer or navigation system causing the car to become a hazard to the driver and passengers, and to other cars and pedestrians. In such a case, I would want to be able to override the system and take control.
because its an appropriate response to a concern people have about emergency situations
Having an option to switch incase of failure is reasonable.
I feel like if there was any kind of failure on the self-driving aspect of the car the driver would need to step in and actually perform the duties of driving.
These decisions are very appropriate because a machine in many cases makes decisions without there being feelings involved, and that is what makes us humans take the right decisions in an emergency.
Simply not OK. Offputting and odd.
I would NEVER ride in a self driving car. If I did I'd want AT LEAST the option to over ride the system
I think the company is being very responsible. Technology can only do so much but in case of an emergency or technological glitch, the human needs to take control of the vehicle to remain safe.
I have heard about self driving cars crashing, in the news. It seems obvious. This is bad technology to let the car have full control without a kill switch option.

I think there are times where this may be needed.  At the same time, if every single car had automatic driving, then the cars could talk to each other and never crash.  So it may be a good thing in the mean time, but in the long run, it will probably be unnecessary.

I think the human driver should always have the choice of switching between self-driving and human-driving modes because there are situations wherein the human has more considerations in terms decision making.
It makes the cars overridable from even the slightest touch of controls that are, for all purpose, ergonomically designed to be held or pressed. It's just asking for mistakes without being realized.
I think this is wise, in case people in the car are uncomfortable with the driverless mechanism. At least you have an out if you don't like the driverless car.
Because the CEO wants people to have as much freedom as possible on the road, while also remaining safe which is very much necessary.

Because there is error on a self driving car that can be avoided by the decision of a human driver.  If the human see a car making the wrong decision, they can jump in and accident and death will be avoided.
I like the fact that he's trying new ways. it might be a little dangerous though.
I think this is the most and safe fair option. Technology can make mistakes and people should be able to take control if necessary.
The safety of the auto driving would be higher but in an emergency the human might need to take control

giving consumers options as to how much human interaction can override self driving cars appeals to different comfort levels among consumers concerning their confidence in self driving cars.  The more hands-on performance driver will appreciate the use of brakes, gas or steering inputs to override the self driving mode.
Because when a unexpected glitch due any number of reasons occurs the human driver/passenger will be able to take control and avoid danger.

I don't like the idea of self-driving cars in the first place; there's always a chance that something will go wrong, that the person will be crashed into by another car that ISN'T self-driving and can't get out of the way fast enough, or that the person just might want to change their mind about where they're going. I prefer the freedom to drive however I want; having complete control helps me to relax while on the road.
It doesn't seem like a dangerous choice the CEO made, but it isn't ethical to do this kind of experiment without informing the consumer.
Humans can still be smarter than machines
If people choose to have self driving cars then they should have some control over them. If they want to drive them their selves then they may.
This makes the most sense from a consumer perspective. You have the choice of using your self-driving mode or taking control as you see fit.
The CEO or the company could be held liable in an instance where an individual is in a serious accident where the car was taking over and the human could not intervene in order to prevent accients.
Human override is important in emergency situations. Combination of modern technology and human wisdom, experience, and reflexes works best together.
Well, it's an experiment, so I wouldn't say that either option given is appropriate or inappropriate. They have similar functions but are executed differently.

When it comes to any type of machine,  humans should always have an option to ultimately control the machine,  in this case, a car. It just add another level of overall safety in case the car itself fails.
People should have the choice to control their own cars if they want to.
I am still very skeptical about complete self driving car. I think people should be able to switch modes at easy.
Human error is much more likely than machine error.

It's appropriate that the CEO gives people and option between self driving and human driving cars. However, the option may confuse others or make it difficult for self driving cars to operate properly.
CEO being selfish
I think it would be the safest way to make sure that drivers are safe in case of emergency. There should be a way to override it just in case.
I don't think the company should sell cars that they are testing.
Everyone should be able to manually drive their car, robotic or not. It's much safer in some cases, and decisions are better made by man than machine.

It's appropriate in the suggested situation that the computer makes a erroneous judgement call.  At least the human would have control to possibly avoid the mistake.  But the motivation behind autonomous cars is that the computer will made choices that are safer and better than human drivers so giving humans ability to interfere with the computer's decisions conflicts with the entire motivation behind self-driving vehicles.
I don't think it matters. What about human error?
I'm all for technology and innovation and I firmly believe driver less cars are the safest way to go.
The override that the CEO wants to put inside the cars would help convince those people who are scared of buying self-driving cars. It would also help those already with self-driving cars feel safer.

It scares me very much over the fact I would have no control over the car. The fact that there is an override makes me really happy. I don't like giving up control and in a case of life or death I want to be the lead.
Computers cannot make decisions like people can and we need to have the ability to take over.  Also, there might be a time when we would want to drive.
The ceo is trying to keep us safe by allowing two different safety options and checking witch one is more efficient.

This gives the driver the option to take over in a scenario where the self driving car could pose a hazard. An example of this would be the car stopping on a rail road track when a train is coming. The driver could use the lever and manually drive the car out of harms way.

This is a test of two alternative systems; the lever system is similar to switching to cruise control; the other system is similar to an "emergency" response that would allow the driver to immediately take control of the vehicle.
I chose that option because of what the CEO said, his statement does not carry all that much validation.
It's appropriate to run experiments to test the effectiveness of each solution.
It would be difficult to drive a car if you touch one of these features that can be overrided. It is easy for people to accidentally hit the parts of the car also.
You should have the option to switch back and forth
Because it makes the most sense. Its important to have a failsafe.
The human driver of the vehicle should always have final say over the actions of their vehicle.

I think that as long as the drivers get to choose which car they want to use then it is appropriate. If they randomly get a completely autonomous without wanting that, then I think it would be an issue. People should be able to decide what sort of autonomy they are comfortable with,
It is good for the CEO to put in a safety control feature in the car. It is not as quick to use a lever for that purpose, but it is still an option that works.
There is nothing wrong with his decision, but it may not be the right one either.
Technology is still capable of failing, and having an option to manually control the vehicle could help prevent any accidents caused by technically issues with the automated system.
I agree with his decisions because I would want my decision to be better than the cars. I think that I might be able to see something that the car doesn't see.
It's a proven fact that you can't always rely on machines to do the work as they can sometimes fail.

Because it's new experience for me , I would like to try it ,and  really appreciate the cars companies
to development that .

I think he made a appropriate decision because, if theres an emergency the driver can take control instead of allowing the car to do it. Also, if the driver is scared that the car might not stop or is going to fast they can take control which may give the driver a sense of ease

This would be considered a controlled experiment, where everything about the vehicle is the same except the mode of where individuals switch from automated to self-driver mode.  The only concern would be if there was an emergency where drivers would need to drive themselves.  If the CEO forsees injury as a result of having to pull a lever, then they are ethically bound not to use the lever.  The CEO should give the driver the option to choose an option and fully disclose the risk involved in each choice.

I think it's good to have the option to take over controlling the vehicle if need to. It would make me a little bit nervous to purchase a vehicle that completely drove itself and not knowing if something malfunctioned I would be able to stop it or not. I would feel a bit more secure knowing that I had that option.
Humans should be paying attention to their driving and be able to override a self driving car if necessary. But not be texting and other distractions.
Because the consumer may have no idea what car they are getting it may pose a dangerous situation to them.

If the driving conditions become dangerous, I would want to be in control instead of a computer.  Bad weather, bad traffic, bad condition of road, not being on a lined road at all, all of these I would want to be in control
It's better to be in control of your own car. If the system miscalculates you can get into a accident.
It seems the safest option.
I'm not really sure. It just seems like a good way to conduct a test.
The CEO's priority is to protect people, while also preserving the self-driving feature of the car. His move was a smart one that fulfilled both priorities.

I chose this option because I do believe that human drivers need the option to override the self-control computer of the car in case the self-control capabilities are not functioning properly, and if the human driver needs to take control of the wheel for whatever purposes.
Because in this way people have freedom to drive so that emergencies would be prevented
As a driver, i want freedom to let the drive the car if I need to do so
It gives the drivers options to feel in control.
I think it's important for the driver to be able to override the self driving feature if the driver decides it is necessary for safety.
If consumers all pay the same price for the same product, then they should come with all the same options and features for each and every consumer
I'd feel better if I could override a self-driving car in case of emergency. I also like to drive, and would like to do it myself from time to time.

Itâ€™s important to be able to switch to self-driving mode in case there is an emergency where the machine fails.  Machines/robots/automatons cannot be completely trusted 100% and thus it is necessary to have a fallback.
Computers have more potential for safety than people. Just that, in theory, cars will be talking to each other and have more info.

The CEO's main concern is to have a self-driving car while still allowing drivers to maintain their freedom. By providing the two options to allow drivers to determine which method is most appropriate for them, the CEO is allowing individuals to have the freedom to determine which method they would prefer.
I like this option, since I am someone who likes to drive and even though I would use the self-drive feature especially in heavy traffic, I'd like the option of driving myself

the idea seems to have the best of both worlds.  the driver can take advantage of the benefits of "self driving," but have the peace of mind of knowing he/she can switch back to human driving if he desires.
I chose this option because i personally would want and need some control over driving my own car. I think the CEO is being responsible and really cares and has his customers safety in mind
It makes it so it can help those who need extra help

We need to care more about cancer prevention and people's welfare. If there is no additional cost added to this and the customers receive their initial ancestry results they originally paid for, all is well with this in my mind.

Because the doctor is willing to help other people by thinking wisely. The option to view or not to view their result is a good decision because it can greatly help with the patient's level of anxiety
ITS SOMETHING THAT I WOULD BE INTERESTED IN. ITS ON MY MIND IF I WOULD GET IT OR NOT

I think it may be an appealing option for the business to attract extra customers. If people don't want to see it, they don't have to. It's not necessarily the best way to go about this, but I don't see it doing additional harm.

We're not given information about whether or not the customers are given the choice to opt into genetic testing about dementia from the outset, so I'll assume the customers were not given the choice from the beginning. Being given the choice of whether or not to view their dementia risk after the testing has already been performed is inappropriate because it has no bearing on the fact that the test was performed without the customer's express consent.

It should be the customers' decision whether they want this test done; this could be traumatizing if results support probability for developing dementia. This is a very sensitive issue, and the director doing the test may put the customers at risk of possibly having this health information exposed to others, which could have very negative consequences.

I chose the director's decision is somewhat appropriate because preventative healthcare is vital to combating conditions such as cancer and dementia.  In addition, early diagnosis has been dramatically shown to increase survival and quality of life.

It's always good to let people know if they are at risk in certain ways. Cancer is a disease that is very dependable on when its detected so knowing you are at risk would help prevent it in the future.
It could be life saving to know early on. It's better to know if you run a higher risk to developing cancer compared to the average.
It can be beneficial for people to learn things about what diseases they can get.  Genetics can determine these things.
I cannot make an informed decision without knowing if customers opted into receiving this knowledge or not.

The consumer can choose to not have the DNA testing done if they don't want to know about the cancer risks. However, I think the company should have surveyed prospective buyers to see if cancer was the one health-related test they wanted run.
I think it would be good to know. The doctor could be preventing future health risks.
As long as the results are kept secret, I think it is fine to do this.  The person gets to choose whether or not to see the results, and I believe no harm is done.

People aren't agreeing to the extra test, only the ancestry test.  If they want it to happen they should sign on for it in the agreement with the company, not simply be told later their health risks via DNA were tested across the board without their asking but that their consolation is that they may view it.  It is an invasion of privacy.

It sounds like the doctor gave people the option of viewing the results, which I think some people would appreciate if it wasn't at an extra cost. If people don't want to know, they aren't exposed to the information.

If the customers want to know what their risks are, they should be able to find out if they want. They should be informed on what they are being tested for so they can make a sound decision on what they are asking to know.

I do not think the company is justified in testing for dementia without prior consent of the patient. Health information is confidential and private, and the company should be straightforward and open about their intent so that the patient can opt out before sending in their sample rather than after the sample has been taken and tested.
i think everyone should know about their results

Cancer is much more deadly. Since cancer is treatable to a certain extend if caught early enough, and as far as I know dementia is not. It's unethical for the company to decide who gets checked for what

The customers signed on for genetic testing to learn about ancestry.  If there were an option of having another test done, they should be told up front, not after the fact . That is very unethical and I would hope that is against the law.  I would be furious!
This would be inappropriate if consumers didn't know but that information is not available in this prompt. It could be appropriate if agreed to.
I think that the health related test is appropriate however I would think that the customer could choose which test to run rather than the researcher making a random choice

I don't see why it would be inappropriate to offer to provide information that could be useful to a patient's health. They have the choice of whether or not they want to see the health genetics tests or not.

I am not sure if the director decided to run the experiment without the knowledge of the people. If he did, that would make it inappropriate because the people should know their being tested and approve it. If it was approved, then it's not fair to test half for cancer and the other half for dementia.
I feel like the research director is looking out for the customers well being. If I participated in the genetic testing and something negative showed up on the test I would like to know.

I'm unclear on whether the customers know these tests are being done in addition to the ancestry.  If not, I think it is wrong for the director to run them.  They should only be done if someone requests them and then whichever the customer chooses rather than randomly.
nice
Not really sure if it is or isnt. Guess the extra testing doesn't have to be done, but seems arbitrary and random to just give half one and half the other.

Unless the company has gotten permission from the users to use their material to test for this, it's completely inappropriate for them to make the unilateral decision to do this.  I know they're all only trying to help, but it's up to the end user to decide if they want to have this tested or not.
I THINK THAT THIS IS A WONDERFUL THING TO KNOW ABOUT ONES HEALTH.  I WOULD WANT TO KNOW AS MUCH AS I COULD ABOUT MY HEALTH AND POSSIBLE ILLNESSES.

I agree that many or most people would likely want to learn about their risk for dementia. However, I believe that more serious diseases such as cancer would be better choices for this single risk screening.
I think the testing and the choice of whether to view the test results should be up to the individual customer.
The doctor should consult with patients prior to conducting the tests.  It is inappropriate to conduct the test without patient's consent.
It provides more information about the person that they wouldn't know otherwise.

Because if the researcher can find that there could be a way to determine a genetic disposition through his research I think it's a good thing he's testing for it. And I think giving people the option to review the results is appropriate because maybe some people won't want to know the results.
I chose the option because the test is suppose to be for ancestry. Testing for health related problems should not be included in the test by this company in my opinion.

Those taking the genetic tests should be informed prior to taking the test... I think it's inappropriate (unethical) to just sneak that test in that way, otherwise.  It demonstrates a real lack of transparency...
even though customers signed up to learn about ancestry, it gives customers more incentive to learn about their ancestry
Health should not be an experiment and be complete to all
They should not be randomly testing people without their consent.
I think it's a good choice
Cancers are the most likely possible future health problem, so if he can only choose one other thing to test for, I think that's best.

I feel that it is mostly appropriate. Maybe I'm a little biased because I personally would be interested in knowing my risks. However, it's a little inappropriate to choose what someone will be tested for or to use their genetic material for what you(researcher) chooses to, even if the customer has the choice of knowing the results or not.

I believe that it is somewhat appropriate to pre-test for illnesses and diseases ahead of time.  This can enable medical practitioners to start treatment early and to possibly even prevent diseases from manifesting.
People have the right to know if they are prone to develop dementia. Have or potentially developing a disease you cannot control is not inappropriate.

As long as the customers know up front that they will also be tested for this, whether they choose to know the results or not, it is ultimately up to the customer if they want to use the service provided.

I do not find the director's choice appropriate or inappropriate. I believe there is a demand for this service and people who would be against the demand. It is ultimately a personal choice that I have no ethical opinion on.
I don't feel like this is something that should be randomly decided. It seems like the people should have a say as to which test they get.

First, having someone else learn about my health info without my permission is not okay with me.  Second, if someone is going to offer such tests, they should be allowed to choose which one is run - they can then decide which test will be the most relevant or useful to them.
I think it's important for people to become more aware of their health and learn how to improve it. It is important to share this type of research to society.
I think customers should be able to have the choice of which test they want.

There are many decisions of different diseases that might be appropriate to choose from like dementia, cancer and heart disease. It was a judgement decision and dementia does affect many people, also people are living older. I think it would be better to let the person choose what disease they wanted to check for, probably one that is genetically relevant to their family history.
It seems somewhat inappropriate that they do/would do that.
I think it's appropriate to best generate a conclusion without having any implied bias on the study. It won't be definitive but statistically will provide a better hypothesis.
They shouldn't be able too do that because they can't diagnose like that. It would scare a lot of people.

I think it is very appropriate to give the customer the option to choose whether or not they want to view their results.
The fact that they are also testing for the risk of dementia later on will afford the customer some preventative actions.
Doesnt seem like he collected consent. This being said customers have the choice to view or not. Neutral
I think its the director's ultimate decision.
Not sure about the legality. H.I.P.P.A. laws, patient-doctor confidentiality

Even though he can't test your history for all of the possible health risks, dementia is still a very high risk health risk,so finding out if you can possibly develop this in the future,its good to know now

I believe that illness testing should be ordered by the customers, I think that no one can test me for something I did not give permission to. On the other hand early detection of cancer or knowing that you are in the risk category could give you few more years or need to total prevention of the disease.
If this is a free service (which is implied) then it is a win win for customers, even though it would be great if they could get both tests performed.

It isn't a problem with the test itself, but more about where that information will end up. If it was for purely research reasons, that's fine. But the chance of it ending up with for profit insurers or other commercial ventures it too high and not in the best interest of the customers.
It would be good to know of health risks that I may be susceptible to. I would like to know my health.

It would be nice to know while I'm getting tested for my ancestry to have an additional test run as long as this test does not cost me. I think it would important to know i I would be prone to dementia.
I think it's a nice option, but doesn't really have to do with an ancestry test.
I work with the elderly and I think it is a great thing to know if you run the risk of dementia so that you can take preventative measures earlier in life.

I think people should get tested on their own if they're concerned about certain health risk. Therefore, it is not up to the health professional to provide a full report. Therefore, overall, I think it's appropriate. However, if the genetics diretor notices something very concerning in genes, he should feel a little morally obligated to tell them

It is somewhat appropriate because he is seeing if health related issues will matter to the customers. He is giving a choice if you want to know the results, so it is not like he is forcing you to know.
it is a terrible disease that a lot of people struggle with later in life. if they had a heads up they could plan for that period of life. knowing may help end of life planning.
I think it helps people in the future. They have some sort of idea if they might develop it or not and maybe take some action for the future.

I think that its a cool idea and the experiment will help them see what works
It's optionable for the consumer so it doesn't not affect them negatively
It causes no harm to the customer as long as it's not more costly.  The customer has the option to view it or not.
becuase they are  telling you what to expect and knowing thre reason for the test it is appropriate.

It seems odd that the director makes the decision rather than the customer. I think because it is related to health information, they should provide consent to have the test done and select the appropriate unless they have agreed to be randomly assigned to a test. Otherwise, I think it is unethical.

Because unless that option was made available to the consumer before requesting the ancestry test, it violates their rights and is not being totally honest about what their DNA results and genetic material is being used for. Customers should have the right to make that request on their own.

If somebody is not interested in finding out about their health in the first place, it is inappropriately intrusive to order a test on them, just because you have some material with which to run a test. People are given an option at a late point, which is the only slightly positive aspect of this.
I don't have an opinion on what he did. Some may find it invasive and some may find it helpful.

It is only somewhat appropriate because the director should ask the person which test they would have to be performed. The person may have additional insight, which could help the director choose the test that would be more useful.

Although the option of not getting tested for dementia is not optional, the option to view the result is, and therefore it is okay because there is no harm if you don't know your result and that information.

It should be up to the customers as to whether or not this is checked, not him. I know that once they have the DNA, they could check everything at once, but it should still be down to the individual. The records should also be destroyed afterwards.

It is very helpful to know about family health conditions and ways to prevent future diseases.  Knowing if you have genetic mutations would be very helpful.

While there are some concerns about how the privacy of this data will be protected during the transmission to the patient, in general, giving patients more information if they freely choose to seek it out is a good thing.
If I paid for this I would like the most information I could get and knowing about these risks could be helpful
I think most people would prefer not to know if they had a genetic condition that could not be prevented or cured. It would just create more worry while there would be nothing they could do about it.
It's very important to always do your past research, in order to move forward with anything that is future related. Taking the right precautions for preventions.
People deserve to know if they are at risk so they can make the appropriate steps to get better.  The CEO is doing the right thing.
Because this will give a person an opportunity to know about their health. Even if nothing can be done it is good to know what you can expect about your health in the future.
Because he could prevent risks.

I think genetic testing for health issues is very important for people especially if they do know anything about their family history. This could help prevent a terminal medical problem later in life. This would be great for a CEO to offer this and put the quality of life over a business decision.
It's better to know if you have any genetic risks for conditions, regardless of whether they're preventable, because the more you know about yourself, the better choices you can make.

I'd say very appropriate, because he is already offering one service and is giving the consumer the Option of seeing more, not forcing those results on them. I THINK PEOPLE HAVE RIGHT TO KNOW IF THEY WANT TO KNOW WHAT PROBLEM THEY MAY FACE IN THE FUTURE
I think all people should be offered the same treatment in this scenario, especially for awareness sake. I think the CEO should make a concrete decision and not a split one.

I think it is appropriate because the CEO is allowing people to see results of diseases they can prevent or reduce their risk for. This allows people to lives healthier lives and maximize their chances of avoiding the disease.

I think i is good because some people want to know, probably not only for themselves, but their offspring or loved ones.So they should have the right to know.  However, for some of us, that don't want to know, it's good there would be the option where we could choose to opt out.
It will benefit families in the long run. Families will be able to take steps to make sure that they don't experience stress based on their children's potential condition.

I felt the CEO's decision is very appropriate because as someone in a position of power, he should help people as much as he can, which is exactly what he wants to do. Thus I really appreciate that he would go out of his way to help people treat their health risks or see if they are vulnerable to any. Sure there might be worries that the CEO may be gathering all these sensitive information for their own gain, but I feel that is not what he wants to achieve.
I think that this can induce panic if some people, but it can also help people prepare for a genetic mutation and take the necessary steps for possible prevention.
it should be looked at a service to consumers to better themselves, however, the security has to be tight because this could be very sensitive information
He's testing on humans without their complete knowledge
If people want to see these results and get this kind of information it seems very appropriate for the company to provide it to the consumer. I don't see why they wouldn't provide the service.
It is a good idea to have this option readily available for customers that want to take advantage. The only thing that bothers me is if insurance companies could get a hold of this information.
The CEO is helping people so this is appropriate. He wants to stop people from becoming sick, which is the right thing to do.
As he will offer the other half the option to see if they have any genetic risks for health conditions
I think it was great of the CEO to do this and give the people the opportunity .  It makes him look like a good guy and it probably helps the clients out alot.

I think that either way the CEO is trying to help his clients. I think that this is a step in the right direction, alerting all clients about any existing conditions that are preventable or curable so that they can take action to do so. In addition, he is offering additional information that can be made available upon request. But perhaps all clients should learn about both the preventable and unpreventable diseases and illnesses so that they are aware and can take appropriate action.
If you're going to go so far as to research your heritage it makes perfect sense to me to look further into your medical history to see what ailments you could possibly contract.
People have every right to know what health risks they have, even if there is nothing that can be done about them.
If I was researching my genealogy and it turned up a health-threatening genetic mutation, I would certainly want to be made aware of it.
If you know you have these traits than youcan do things that help treat it or prevent it.
The more you know about your health the better.
I think it's a fine experiment. So long as people have a choice in finding out
It is appropriate because he is helping others. I would take the test.

It's a test trial so he can see which option people respond to better and I agree with his decision both ways because the people have to find out anyways whether it's good or bad news, but it's just how they can take the news that counts

I think the CEO should offer all the relevant risks available to the client, preferably on a scale where the degree of the risk determines its placement, with minor risks being the first to be discussed and severe risks being the last. I thought the decision was somewhat inappropriate because it seems that the company lacks any real basis for only sharing treatable risks versus those that cannot be treated, especially given that a client could opt to view the complete results in either option. I'd feel me trust in a company were abused if I learned they carried out a strategy such as the one described above. It just doesn't seem ethical to withhold information based on random conditions, only then to offer the complete set of results, as if that's supposed to appear anything but an arbitrary choice at that point. I'd say the decision was very inappropriate if not for the fact that the CEO's company is offering a service of an apparently great worth to people, and potentially lifesaving for clients.

First, I am concerned about the reliability of that information.  Does the data collection and analyses meet medical standards?  I recall reading an article about identical triplet women from Minnesota who did the DNA ancestry testing and received differing results.  This implies the quality of testing is probably best described "as for entertainment use only".

If the information is provided solely to the person for their sole use and disclosure, then I find that use somewhat acceptable.  I would strongly advise that person to confirm this information with redundant testing from a qualified medical practitioner in which the testing meets medical standards.

My concern is if that information enters the public domain, either by hacking or by sale to others.  Could that information then be misused?  We have had to many breaches of major systems (Equifax, etc.).   Could someone be bombarded with unsolicited emails / phishing / spam because the hacked / sold information indicates someone has a medical condition?  Could a person be denied a financial transaction (e.g. loan), if the information indicates a high risk of an early death?  If a third party (e.g. lender) uses this information, are they required to disclose it?  Does the victim (e.g. the prospective borrower) then need to fight it in court or get official medical testing to prove / disprove.
I think they all should receive the same options instead of splitting them in half

I'm torn on this. On the one hand, I think people should generally be allowed unfettered access to information about themselves, including genetic conditions.On the other hand, people who opt to learn about genetic mutations, particularly those without treatment and possible devastating long-term prognoses, may be totally unprepared for the results they receive. The scenario, as described, doesn't really provide any path for assistance to those who may receive very bad news. I might also add that genetic testing is not foolproof, so I'd be very hesitant about allowing a company to send out missives that basically say, "Here are your results. By the way, you have a fatal disease."

The system is set up to only allow customers to contact people who are recommended as a match. The CEO of the dating service wants to improve customer satisfaction by introducing a new way to match people together. He thinks of a way to do this. So, he decides to program his website to report users are a match when they are somewhat similar (but not TOO similar) to each other, based on the questions they answered.
Sometimes the matching algorithms are so tight you get very few hits. Loosening the guidelines will give people more options.

It depends on whether the service is free or not. I think that if the service is not free, then this would be inappropriate as the users are probably expecting the best kind of service possible from the dating site, and would not want to be used as guinea pigs. Generally speaking most couples should have some differences between them, partially because it's healthy to disagree sometimes and work through those issues, and partially because our lovers don't necessarily have to exist as extensions or reflections of ourselves; they're people with entirely different life trajectories before, during, and after meeting us. Besides, just because two people are similar doesn't mean they're compatible; using myself as an example, although I am usually reserved, I tend to prefer slightly extroverted people who can compensate for my occasional rigidity. In exchange, I provide a balanced temperament and ability to work behind the scenes when direct action is ineffective.
